titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Read prayers this morning and Sterne’s Sermon 5. On the Story of Elijah, and the widow of Zarephath; a Charity Sermon; and one of the best in the Collection— There is a defect in this, and in all these discourses, of method— They are desultory, consisting of a number of observations and Sentiments, with little mutual connection together— Parts of this Sermon are deeply pathetic; but they are intermixed with others of argument, and with remarks of so little interest that they do not form a consistent whole. The anecdote concerning Alexander of Pheres, comes in after one of the passages of warmest feeling, and operates as a damper upon it— I walked before Breakfast alone, and before dinner with Charles— Evening visit from Count and Countess Soltykoff, but they left Cards.

2. Dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a diplomatic company; about forty-five persons— The Count told me before dinner, that he believed the grant I had asked for Mr Fulton would be made— That the Emperor had only thought proper to fix a different modification of time— Mr Fulton asked an exclusive privilege for twenty years— But the grants of patents in America, and in England were only for fourteen years— And the Emperor thought proper to allow one year more—the privilege therefore would be for fifteen years, and with the condition annexed that it shall cease and be void; if the first boat should not be in operation in three years— At table I sat between Count Maistre and Count Löwenhielm, and conversed about the American Indians, about Creation, and about the desperate Condition, and almost certain ruin of the French Emperor and Army— I came home immediately after dinner— Mr Krehmer paid us a visit this morning, and renewed his invitation to us, to dinner on Wednesday.— Baron Blome told me that the Swedish expedition against the island of Zeeland was probably postponed; but they now threatened the invasion of Norway. Blome himself has yet the deportment of an assiduous Courtier; and is treated in return with a coldness bordering to say the least upon incivility.

3. Mrs Krehmer came this morning to renew the invitation to us to dinner to-morrow; but Sir Francis d’Ivernois, is confined by a violent, and even dangerous fever, so that he will not be there— I met Mr Harris walking on the quay, and he told me he should be there— Mr Brandel passed the Evening with us— I have begun to hear Charles read the Psalter; and for that purpose use the one in the Common-Prayer Book— The trial of Patience and of Temper, in this occupations sometimes overpowers me— The most painful struggle is to suppress the anger, which the perverseness of indocility occasions— Charles has bad habits of pronunciation, for which I can account only from his learning at once to speak three languages— I take the most unremitting pains to correct them, and am so long unsuccessful that it almost discourages exertion— There is a wilfulness of adhering to error, and a sluggishness in remembering correction which baffle perseverance itself— I endeavour to mingle instruction with sports, but so averse is human nature to learn, that the sport which was delightful in itself, becomes irksome from the moment that I connect it with a lesson— It still however employs much of my time— Mrs Adams takes the spelling Book.— After all, few children of Charles’s age, read so well in one language as he does in two.

4. Went out with Catherine to Ochta, and dined at Mr Krehmer’s— Mr Harris was there; Mrs Pitt, the wife of the English clergyman—and two Mr Gisborne’s, sons of Dr Gisborne the author, who live with Mr Krehmer— There was much political conversation, characteristic, as well of the present state of affairs, as of the feelings of the Speakers— The Passions of almost all the politicians whom I now see and hear are concentrated upon the head of one man— It seems almost universally to be considered that the destinies of mankind, hang upon his life alone, and in proportion to the force of this sentiment is the ardour for his death— I know not how it has been with former conquerors during their lives, but I believe there never was a human being who united against himself such a mass of execration and abhorrence as this man has done— There is indeed on the other hand, an admiration of him equally enthusiastic, as for every great conqueror there always must be; but I have never yet seen the person, by whom he was regarded with affection.— We returned home late this Evening— The first fall of snow, this Season was this day.

5. Mr Harris called upon me this morning. He had a letter from his nephew, who was shipwrecked the second Night after he sailed from Cronstadt, on a rock 40 versts distant from the land. He had in a small open boat, with the Captain and four men, safely reached Fredericshaven from whence his letter was dated— He was to proceed for Gothenburg by land— Mr Harris had also a letter to Mr Sparrow from the Captain of a British armed vessel at Cronstadt, stating that a Seaman belonging to the American ship Maria Theresia, named Stephen Green, had reported himself to him as a British Subject, and claimed his protection as such— He therefore requested that an enquiry, should be made if he were really a British Subject, and if so that his wages should be paid him, and a regular discharge given him— Mr Harris said he had ordered Sparrow to give no other answer than to claim the man; who is a native of Massachusetts; and as such entered on board the Maria Theresia.
The Ladies, Mr Smith and Charles went this Evening to the Theatre. I spent it at home— Read the preface to the Manuel des Artistes, which is a dissertation upon painting, containing many valuable remarks. My health is indifferent, and I am almost disqualified for reading to any good purpose in the Evening.

6. The official account of the Battle at Malo-Jaroslawetz 24 October is now published. Kutuzoff as usual claims the victory; but his army again retreated after it— As yet no decisive proof appears, whether the object of the French army was to cover its own retreat or to penetrate further into Russia— That they do not expect, or intend to return to Moscow appears certain— I wrote to Mr Russell, and employed the Evening partly with Charles, and the remainder in reading Gisborne’s principles of Moral and Political Philosophy— It contains frequent objections to the principles, and to the reasoning of Paley.— I was still quite unwell.

7. I went with the Ladies, and Charles this Evening to the theatre where we saw performed La Vestale— The poem by Jouy, and the music by Spontini— I continue walking before Breakfast and before dinner, but I suffer much from the severity of the Climate. I had no interruption this day, and yet scarcely did any thing—

8. Read prayers, and Sterne’s Sermon 6. on the story of the Pharisee and the Publican.— There is one passage in it approaching to levity; but which perhaps it would savour too much of austerity to proscribe.— I also read several Chapters of Gisborne’s Treatise upon the principles of Moral Philosophy, and in his Enquiry into the duties of Men— The Philosophy is little more than a Book against Paley— Mr Smith heard, and told us of the declaration of War, by Great-Britain, against the United States— My health is yet bad—perhaps because I am too solicitous about it. 9. On taking my usual walk this morning, I found the two Bridges of the Neva gone, and the river about half full of floating ice. The Fontanka Canal, was almost every where frozen over—there has been yesterday and the day before a considerable fall of snow, so that the sledges pass upon it— The thermometer (Reaumur’s) has been from 5 to 7 below 0. the temperature at which the river usually freezes.— Mr Harris called upon me and brought with him some English Newspapers, containing the English Official account of the capture of the British frigate Guerriere, by the Constitution, Captain Hull, and also the dispatches from General Brock, and the shameful capitulation of General Hull and his army in upper Canada.— The Countess Colombi, and her sister Frederica Bode visited the Ladies, and mentioned the decease of General Pardo, the late Spanish Minister here— He died at a small, mean hovel of an inn, upon his journey from this City— General Essen at Riga has taken his daughter a child about fourteen, who was left friendless and alone when her father died. Madame Colombi intends sending for her. Pardo I believe died of a broken heart— He had connected himself with the French party in Spain inextricably, while his feelings were all on the other side— He accepted Office, Military Rank, and a blushing Ribband from Joseph Bonaparte, and yet in all his Conversation, with every body was enthusiastically zealous for the Patriots— There was a contrast between his conduct, and his discourse greater than I ever witnessed in any other man. He had lost his Fortune, and several of his near Relations by the War in Spain— He had been two or three years without pay from the Government that he had consented to serve, and by the new War he was dismissed even from nominal employment without any present provision, or any prospect of future supply, so much as for the subsistence of himself and his daughter; besides a son of 16 or 17 who is at Paris. He was a learned classical scholar; a well taught connoisseur in the fine Arts—a profound theoretical proficient in the Art of War, a lively and pleasant convivial companion, and a man of strong and brilliant genius— I believe if he had possessed firmness and energy of character he would have taken an active part and been a highly distinguished leader, in the Spanish Cause— I omitted this day my second walk; being quite unwell— Read further in Gisborne’s Moral Philosophy.

10. At my early morning walk I found the ice still floating in masses down the Neva; but the river was nearly full— When I walked again before dinner I found the ice was fixed, and the river entirely frozen over— Snow, the greatest part of the day— The Ladies with Mr Smith and Charles went this Evening to the theatre— Mr Plummer passed an hour of it with me— I read the remainder
of Gisborne’s principles of Moral Philosophy, and his Remarks on a decision in the British House of Commons in April 1792 on the abolition of the Slave-Trade— He is a very zealous advocate for this abolition, which has been since legally decreed in England as well as in America— Whether it will eventually be abolished in fact is yet a problem— The trade is beyond question, an abomination, disgraceful to the human character, but there are so many powerful passions and interests concurring to support it, and the efforts to obtain its abolition are themselves so much composed of fashion and faction that I still doubt whether the abolition will be accomplished. I say the motives of the abolitionists were in a great degree fashion and faction; for the Impressment of Seamen is to all intents and purposes a practice as unjust as immoral, as base, as oppressive and tyrannical as the slave-trade. It is in all its most heinous features identically the same crime— In some particulars it is more aggravated— And yet the same members of the British Parliament who have been the greatest zealots for abolishing the Slave-trade, are not only inflexible adherents to the practice of impressments among their own people, but are now waging a rancorous War against the United States, to support the practice of their Officers in impressing men from American Merchant vessels on the high-seas— Every particle of argument that can bear against the slave trade bears with equal force against impressment.— Dr: Gisborne is at least consistent— He admits that the Impressment of Seamen is a violation of the general principles of the English Constitution— And he speaks of it even as applied to British Subjects with disapprobation— He says nothing of the abuse of extending the practice to Americans, and upon American Vessels— And even his censure upon it as applied only to British Subjects is very faint and cold compared with his fervour of passion against the slave-trade. I also read in Smith’s Essays on Philosophical subjects part of his History of Astronomy.

11. Mr Charles Etter came this morning and shewed me his diploma, as Correspondent of the Imperial Academy of Sciences, in this City, to which honour he was elected a few weeks since, for having presented to the Academy the samples of North-American minerals, sent him by Dr Gorham. He had also a very polite letter of thanks from Mr Fuss— From the Emblematical Ornaments upon the Diploma it seems that the Sciences cultivated by the Academy are Belles-Lettres, Chemistry, Anatomy, Mechanics, Natural History, Astronomy and Geography, Physics, and the sublimer Mathematics— The Diploma is signed by Count Alexis Razumofsky, not as President of the Academy; but as Minister of public Instruction throughout the Empire; and by Mr Fuss as perpetual Secretary to the Academy.— Mr Fisher sent me a present of Birds he had killed at a shooting party some days ago— An errand at the shops served as a substitute for my second daily walk. In the Evening I finished reading Smith’s History of Astronomy— A short and unfinished work—ingenious; but fanciful— There seems to be too much philosophical apparatus to account for a thing very simple in itself—the historical part appears to me, more valuable than the theoretical.

12. In my walk before dinner, I saw from the lower quay three men walk over the river upon the ice; but I heard that several persons had this morning been drowned in making the attempt. Mr Fisher, Mr Redwood, Mr Proud, Mr Lawler, Mr J. W. Smith and Mr Plummer dined with us; and the three first also spent the Evening here.— I purchased yesterday a slate for Charles, that he may begin to learn to write upon it.— He made the first trial this day, and was much delighted with his success— Dr Galloway was here; swallowed up as usual in politics— He says there is now nothing but good news— The French army and Emperor are in full retreat, with very heavy losses, and the Russians pursuing with great advantages.

13. Morning visits from Mr Saltus and Mr Delprat, who came to ask my opinion upon the expediency of their selling their ships to Russian or Swedish Subjects, and whether if such sales should be effected by them the vessels would not still be liable to capture by the British, under one of the orders in Council of 11. November 1807— I thought they would— Mr Harris spent part of the Evening with us. The weather has become severely cold for the Season; last Night 10 degrees below 0 of Réaumur— I find myself affected by it in health more than heretofore. Charles is affected by it still more. I read this Evening Smith’s History of Antient Physics and of Logic and Metaphysics; both, like that of Astronomy, fragments.— I regret very much that this work was not finished, and that it was not more particular— I met Count Lowenhielm in my walk before dinner.

14. I walked out this morning, Reaumur’s thermometer being at 12 degrees below 0— The Winter though it commenced a few days later than it did last year; announces itself more severely than I have ever before known it, at so early a period— I had visits from Mr Proud, and Mr Lewis—who is alarmed at the prospect of an alliance offensive and defensive between Russia and Great-Britain;
upon which subject I endeavoured to tranquilize his mind; as much as I could.— Mr Proud thinks that at the approaching Election in America, the federalists would vote for Mr DeWitt Clinton as President, which I did not think probable.— I read this Evening Smith’s Essay on the imitative Arts—Music, Dancing and Poetry— Also a short and very superficial Essay on certain English and Italian verses—on the accent, cesural pause, single, double and treble rhymes, and measure— When it was written the Doctor could not have been acquainted either with the Abbé le Batteux’s theory, nor even Sheridan’s book on the art of reading.— His observations on the accent and cesura, in English heroic verse are altogether incorrect. His observations on the nature of imitation, and the various modes of it in music, dancing, poetry, painting and sculpture are curious, and I believe generally correct— But the theory he deduces from them is questionable.

15. The cold weather continues with increasing severity.— This morning 13 degrees below 0 of Reaumur— I persist nevertheless in my morning walk.— I have a Catarrhal Cold like those which persecuted me the whole of last Winter, and which I am yet not able to shake off— Charles’s health too is affected in a similar manner— I read prayers, and Sterne’s Sermon 7. which he calls a Vindication of Human Nature— On the text “for none of us liveth to himself[”]— The argument of this Discourse is unanswerable; its sentiment affecting, and the principle stated in the text is fully supported by it— In the Evening I read the first of Dr: Mayhew’s Sermons to Young Men; on the text, “Young Men, exhort to be sober-minded[”]— I found it difficult to read loud; and was two or three times nearly compelled to desist.— Our footman Pietro Irosilly was married this Evening; and the nuptials took away for the Evening, most of the other men servants.

16. Pietro brought his bride with him this morning and presented her to me, with a plate of Apples,—according to the custom— I walked again early this morning, and before dinner, but the catarrh still clings to me— Charles also continues quite unwell— My Spirits are affected, more than my reason can either justify or overpower— This Evening I read Smith’s Essay on the External Senses, and we played Cards a couple of hours.

17. I omitted this morning my walk before breakfast, finding it necessary to pay some attention to my health— Charles continues quite unwell— Dr Galloway was twice here this day, and prescribed for him an emetic, which had but a partial operation. I rode to Mr: Meyer’s on the Wasili-Ostrof, for some business that I had with him— I walked home— In the Evening I found my Cold considerably increased. Probably owing to the very means I took for its cure— I read in Gisborne’s Duties of Men Vol 1. and also in Cicero’s Academicks; in the French Translation of Durand.— The weather has moderated, but is now damp and gloomy.

18. I had an entirely sleepless Night; and Charles a very restless one— This day Mrs Adams, myself and Charles were all very unwell. Mrs Adams part of the day extremely ill— I did not walk, but rode out with Catherine— Had a visit from Mr Montreal; and received a letter from Count Romanzoff, in answer to my application in behalf of Mr Fulton— The condition of my family and my own disqualified me, for my usual occupations— Charles’s lessons are suspended, and my attempts both at reading and writing were unavailing.

19. Having had a tolerably good Night’s rest, I found my health this day better than it was yesterday, and I was able partly to resume my proper occupations— My body, mind and Estate are in the hands of God— They are under a severe and painful trial, from which his grace alone can relieve them— Why art thou cast down, Oh my Soul! and why art thou disquieted within me?— Hope thou in God; for I shall yet praise him, who is the health of my countenance, and my God— I rode out with Catherine, and walked home— Passing by Mr Laval’s house, I saw his Carriages just moving off upon his Journey, which has been long protracted, and which the course of Events has now rendered unnecessary— Snow, great part of the day— The Ladies and Mr Smith went to the Theatre— Mr Lewis and Mr Redwood paid us late Evening visits. I employed almost the whole Evening in teaching and amusing Charles— Resumed this day his lessons; upon which I ask the blessing of God.

20. I rose this morning, supposing the day to be breaking; which is now at about 7. O’Clock— On going into my Cabinet and lighting a Candle, I found that what I had taken for day-light was moon-light, and that it was only 5 O’Clock— I employed myself in writing untill the hour for Breakfast— 5 in the morning is precisely the time that I should wish regularly to rise; but after more than a year of assiduous and anxious effort to establish myself in this practice, I am ready to abandon the attempt in despair— The severe Colds which tormented me in succession the whole of last Winter, and untill Midsummer, the situation, sicknesses and misfortunes in my family, have made regular early rising, if not absolutely impossible, at least impracticable, without a degree of tenacity and perseverance of purpose which does not belong to my character— With the first appearance of severe Cold this season I find my health again attacked, precisely as it was last Winter—my wife,
and child are suffering in a manner which distresses me and keeps me in a continual state of painful alarm— A quiet mind is essential to the regularity of nightly repose—health is equally indispensable to that enjoyment— I have neither— I returned this day to my customary exercise of walking before dinner— The early morning walk is yet suspended— In the Evening I began with Charles upon Mr St: Quentin’s General Grammar— The Counters and Tellers, and Cards of Exercises amuse him by their novelty. I shall try the experiment with them; although without much Confidence in this mode of Instruction.— Played at Ombre with the Ladies.

21. I thought myself this morning released from the troublesome Cold that has for some weeks afflicted me; but it came on again in the course of the day and at Night— Its best remedy would perhaps be patience; but that is a quality which I find also dependent upon the physical condition of the body. To be patient requires something more than the mere will— A nervous agitation, an unsteady hand making it exceedingly irksome to write, a flutter of the Spirits, and a perpetual sensation of hurry are among the severest symptoms of the disorder— I nevertheless walked before dinner— Wrote, for about two hours, and devoted the whole Evening to Charles, who was in a lucky humour for reading, not very common with him— I also played Nine-pins with him at least an hour— The exercise is absolutely necessary for him, and it is for me as good as any that I can take in the house— The Ladies and Mr Smith went to the Theatre, and saw Racine’s Iphigénie.

22. A continual Snow-storm the whole day— Dr Galloway was here, full of Russian victories and French disasters.— I rode out with Catherine, but omitted altogether my walking— I read prayers and Sterne’s Sermon 8.—on Time and Chance— It is carelessly written—incorrect in the language, and not sufficiently precise in the doctrine— The truth of the text is clear, but it partakes of that melancholy colour which peculiarly marks the Book of Ecclesiastes— This particular text has an appearance of countenancing the tenet of fatalism— Against which conclusion I think some argument should be introduced by every preacher upon it.— Taken by itself, and without the elucidation of other passages of Scripture, this text might tend to discourage industry and exertion— Solomon had no such intention. His proverbs abundantly prove his estimate of diligence and assiduity— Sterne merely infers by an argument somewhat entangled that the Events of this world are overruled by God’s Providence, and this argument he acknowledges having borrowed from Tillotson— This is a just but a religious consideration— The moral deducible from the text he neglects— I also read the second of Mayhew’s Sermons to Young Men, on Sobriety of Mind as implying a belief of Religion natural and revealed— Charles read a little in the Evening— Mr Smith went out and dined at Mr Krehmer’s at Ochta.

23. My Cold has again apparently, and this time I hope really left me— My wife and Charles also, blessed be God, appear to be recovering health; without which no blessing can be enjoyed. I resume my occupations— Charles reads in the morning to me in the Psalter, and in the Evening in one of the Books for Children lent him by Mrs: Krehmer— He also reads in Dufief’s Grammar and in the spelling Book to his Mother.— I wrote part of a letter, and in the Evening read Dr Gisborne on the Duties of Executive Ministers of State, and of Officers in the Army and Navy.— The Doctor’s principles are generally excellent— The theory of Virtue and of Religion, appears to be well understood and sufficiently inculcated in England— But of Virtue and Religion, as of the Arts and Sciences, is it not true that they are never best practiced where they are taught in the highest perfection. British Ministers of State, and Officers in the Army and Navy seldom act upon the rules of Dr Gisborne— May my own Countrymen act upon them; as far as they are applicable to our Circumstances— We closed the Evening with Cards.

24. Morning visits from Mr Montréal, and from Mr Lawler and Mr J. W. Smith.— Mr Montréal shewed me a letter from Mr Barthe at Moscow; he was there when the French took the City; and narrowly escaped with his life— He lost almost every thing he had there—merchandizes to a very large amount— The account he gives of the devastation of the City, by fire and indiscriminate pillage, nine days successively, is shocking; but agrees with all the others that are received— He says that seven eighths of the City are destroyed— Mr Lawler and Mr Smith had seen Accounts from America, in English News-papers, corroborating Mr Proud’s information that the federalists would coalesce at the approaching Presidential Election with Mr Clinton’s friends, and that they considered his Election as secure— The Ladies went in the Evening to the theatre, where they heard of a new and very great victory of the Russians over the French— Scarcely a day now passes without one— I passed the Evening at home, instructing Charles— Mrs Adams had a morning visit from Countess Colombi— The weather has become more moderate, and it rained all this Evening— I hope my Cold is entirely gone.

25. This morning I received a notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, that a Te Deum would be performed at the Cathedral Church of Kazan, at 1/2 past 11 O’Clock this forenoon, to return thanks for the defeat of the Enemy’s Corps under the command of the Marshals d’Avoust and Ney. I went with Mr Smith accordingly at the hour— It is the greatest victory that the Russians have gained since the War commenced, and is perfectly decisive of the fate of the Campaign, and of the Emperor Napoleon’s main army— It is now morally impossible that the remnant of them should escape— In every probability they are at this hour all prisoners of War— He is lost without resource.— The trophies, among which is d’Avoust’s Marshal’s truncheon were exhibited in the Church— Tchernicheff, who has highly distinguished himself was present; as were General Winzingerode, and his Aid-de-Camp Young Narishkin, the Grand Chamberlain’s Son, who were taken prisoners by a most extraordinary accident, when Winzingerode’s Corps took Moscow, and were retaken by another accident no less extraordinary, on their way as prisoners to France— A few Cossacks of Tchernicheff’s detachment released them— Tchernicheff has been promoted to the rank of a Major-General, and Aid-de-Camp General to the Emperor, and appeared in his new Uniform— Joy and Triumph was upon every Countenance; but upon none with such transport as upon that of Madame Naryshkin, who went about with her Son by the hand, presenting him to all her friends, and saying she had nothing more to ask of Heaven— The Emperor and Imperial family performed their prostrations to the miraculous image of the Virgin; and the Emperor on leaving the Church was greeted with loud shouts of the Populace— After returning home I rode out with Catherine and Charles— Countess Colombi and her Sister Frederica dined and passed part of the Evening with us— Mr Harris visited us at the close of the Evening.— There have been rumours of internal commotions at Paris, in Circulation sometime— They were much exaggerated in the Reports, but accounts from Sweden ascertain that they did take place even before the end of October, and before Napoleon’s disasters had commenced— They were then suppressed; but they afford a presage of violent convulsions when the real Events of the last Month shall be sufficiently known to produce their effect— The Crisis is great and awful beyond all example— Almighty God grant that it may turn to good! to Peace! to the relief of mankind from the dreadful Calamities of unbridled Ambition!

26. I had a sleepless Night, and determined to make this day the experiment of taking the warm bath which I have been some time contemplating but from which I had been rather discouraged by Dr: Galloway; he is no friend to bathing warm or cold. I previously took a short walk and went to the Bath at 3 O’Clock.— I took many precautions on coming out of the bath to prevent the ill-effect of the sudden transition from heat to cold— Experience has proved to me the necessity of them— The Ladies and Mr Smith with Charles went to the Theatre in the Evening— I endeavoured but without success to get some repose— Read a few English Newspapers which Mr Harris brought and lent me this morning.

27. The first part of the Night I was so restless and sleepless that I apprehended the bath had rather been prejudicial than useful— I rested however afterwards, and untill broad day-light this morning— This day I find unequivocal benefit from the Bath— Walked before dinner; read a few pages in Gisborne’s duties of Men—heard Charles in the Psalter, and his English Story-Book; and passed an hour at Cards. Captain Florence, Master of one of the American Vessels at Cronstadt, came to ask my advice what to do with his men;—whom he is obliged to maintain and keep on wages— He dared not sail before Winter on account of the War between America and England. He is here upon freight, and his portage bill has already swallowed up almost the whole proceeds of his Cargo— There is no prospect, that he will be able to go next Summer—his resources are nearly absorbed, and he knows not where or how to obtain relief.— I could give him none; but advised him to wait untill the approach of summer, as at all Events he must; and perhaps in the interval some thing might occur of which he could avail himself to extricate him from his very unpleasant situation.

28. A Stormy day— I rode out with Catherine and Charles; and afterwards took a short walk— The Ladies and Mr Smith went in the Evening to the Theatre— I employed the whole of it with Charles in reading and learning the first lesson of St: Quentin’s Grammar— I am however convinced that he will soon stop short in this pursuit— The plan appears to me excellent for a school; where there are several fellow-learners to stimulate the curiosity and industry of one another— But for a single pupil especially of Charles’s age, I fear it will not succeed— I cheerfully devote to my Child, all the time that I can properly require of him to apply to his own instruction;—though it diverts many hours which I might perhaps better appropriate to my own instruction, or to the production of something more important than teaching a Child the first Elements of knowledge.

29. Mrs Adams was very unwell the whole day—confined to her bed. I nevertheless read prayers to her; and Sterne’s Sermon 9. upon the character of Herod. It was preached on Innocents day, and its purpose is to argue the authenticity of the scriptural account of Herod’s massacre of the Innocents from the character of the Man— It is like the rest of these discourses so ingenious and interesting that one wishes it longer. I have never read any other Sermons that possess this sort of attraction so strongly as Sterne’s. I also read Mayhew’s third Sermon to Young Men—on Sobriety of Mind as implying humility and repentance— These Sermons are of a character very different from Sterne’s, although like them they occasionally contain a stroke of Satire. In the Evening I finished reading Vol 1. of Gisborne’s duties of Men, which is much like a Sermon too— A very useful book of practical morality, written in plain and easy language, and replete with sound sense and honest sentiment— I walked twice this day; and gave the usual portion of time to Charles.

30. I wrote a letter to my mother; which with Charles’s morning and Evening lessons filled up the day— I read however to close the Evening part of Gisborne’s duties of Men—Vol. 2.— One walk before dinner— I began to task Charles with learning Addison’s poetical version of the 23d: Psalm— This was one of the first things that I ever learnt by heart myself; and I remember it from the age of seven years— As I have not hitherto accustomed Charles to learn recitations by heart, he is very reluctant at this new toil; I could not prevail upon him perfectly to acquire this day even the first Stanza of six lines.— But after keeping him about half an hour to it, postponed the remainder of the lesson untill to-morrow.

Day. My State of health during the Month now just elapsed, has compelled me to depart from the regularity of my rising hours; though I have risen with only two or three exceptions before full day-light— The Employment of my time continues as it has been disposed for many Months before; but Charles absorbs it more and more— I have now very seldom any interruption from visitors, and still more seldom go abroad into Company— Almost all those with whom I formerly associated are gone, and with those who have come to take their places, the Circumstances of the times forbid me to associate— Time, when I enjoy the blessing of health and the use of my eyes, can never hang heavy upon my hands— I have now scarcely any thing but leisure, and if I bestowed on some important pursuit two thirds of the time I allow to Charles, I should have little cause for self-dissatisfaction— As it is, I cannot escape from self-reproach for losing so many hours in unprofitable occupation; and for indolence which I have not strength of mind to overcome.
